summary: This document is an email chain from February 2019 discussing a meeting to review a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email, forwarded on February 24, 2019, references a pitch made earlier that week by lawyers, including Pete Skinner, representing a victim who was 16 at the time of the alleged abuse. The email notes Epstein's history, his 2007 non-prosecution agreement, and the complexity of the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of a potential sex trafficking case. Described as a financier with multiple homes who allegedly had dozens of victims, with criminal conduct that may have continued past a known 2007 agreement.

persons.name: Pete Skinner
persons.context: One of the lawyers who, along with two others, came in earlier in the week to pitch a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Pete Skinner is part of a legal team pitching a case against Jeffrey Epstein on behalf of a victim.

events.title: Lawyer pitch on Epstein case
events.description: Earlier in the week of this email, Pete Skinner and two other lawyers pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the recipient's office.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida in 2007.

keyFacts: Lawyers, including Pete Skinner, pitched a new sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York in February 2019.
The case involved a victim who was 16 years old when allegedly prostituted by Epstein.
The email states Epstein 'apparently had dozens of victims' and it was unclear if his criminal conduct had stopped.
The 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida was noted as a complicating factor.
The correspondence shows active consideration of prosecuting Epstein in early 2019, prior to his arrest later that year.
